introduction.p: Perhaps the most useful theorem of this chapter is Theorem which shows how limits interact with arithmetic. In this (optional) section we will prove both the arithmetic of limits Theorem and the Squeeze Theorem. Before we get to the proofs it is very helpful to prove three technical lemmas that we'll need. The first is a very general result about absolute values of numbers:

proof.p:
Notice that for any real number x, we always have -x,x\le|x| and either |x|=x or |x|=-x. So now let x,y \in \mathbb{R}. Then we must have either
|x+y|&= x+y &&\le |x|+|y|
or |x+y|&= -x-y &&\le |x|+|y|
In both cases we end up with |x+y| \le |x| + |y|.

introduction.p: The second lemma is more specialised. It proves that if we have a function f(x) \to F as x \to a then there must be a small window around x=a where the function f(x) must only take values not far from F. In particular it tells us that |f(x)| cannot be bigger than |F|+1 when x is very close to a.

statement.p: Let a \in \mathbb{R} and let f be a function so that \ds \lim_{x \to a} f(x) =F. Then there exists a \delta \gt 0 so that if 0 \lt |x-a| \lt \delta then we also have |f(x)| \leq |F|+1.

introduction.p: The proof is mostly just manipulating the \epsilon\delta definition of a limit with \epsilon=1.

proof.p:
Let \epsilon = 1. Then since f(x) \to F as x \to a, there exists \delta \gt 0 so that when 0 \lt |x-a| \lt \delta, we also have |f(x)-F| \leq \epsilon=1. So now assume 0 \lt |x-a| \lt \delta. Then
-\epsilon &\leq f(x) - F \leq \epsilon & \text{rearrange a little}
-\epsilon+F &\leq f(x) \leq \epsilon+F
Now \epsilon+F \leq \epsilon+|F| and -\epsilon+F \geq -\epsilon-|F|, so
-\epsilon-|F| &\leq f(x) \leq \epsilon+|F|
Hence we have |f(x)| \leq \epsilon+|F| = |F|+1.

introduction.p: Finally our third technical lemma gives us a bound in the other direction; it tells us that when x is close to a, the value of |f(x)| cannot be much smaller than |F|.

statement.p: Let a \in \mathbb{R} and F\ne0 and let f be a function so that \ds \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = F. Then there exists \delta \gt 0 so that when 0 \lt |x-a| \lt \delta, we have |f(x)| \gt \frac{|F|}{2}.

introduction.p: Now we are in a position to prove Theorem. The proof has more steps than the previous \epsilon-\delta proofs we have seen. This is mostly because we do not have specific functions f(x) and g(x) and instead must play with them in the abstract and make good use of the formal definition of limits.

We will break the proof into three pieces. The minimum that is required is to prove that
\lim_{x \to a} ( f(x) + g(x) ) &= F+G
\lim_{x \to a} f(x) \cdot g(x) &= F\cdot G
\lim_{x \to a} \frac{1}{g(x)} &= \frac{1}{G}\quad\text{if } G\ne 0.
From these three we can prove that
\lim_{x \to a} f(x) \cdot c &= F\cdot c
\lim_{x \to a} ( f(x) - g(x) ) &= F-G
\lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &= \frac{F}{G}\quad\text{if } G\ne 0.
The first follows by setting g(x) = c and using \lim f(x) \cdot g(x). The second follows by setting c=-1, putting h(x) = (-1)\cdot g(x) and then applying both \lim f(x) \cdot g(x) and \lim f(x)+g(x). The third follows by setting h(x) = \frac{1}{g(x)} and then using \lim f(x) \cdot h(x).

Starting with addition, in order to satisfy the definition of limit, we are going to have to show that
|( f(x) + g(x) )-(F+G) | &\text{ is small}
when we know that |f(x)-F|, |g(x)-G| are small. To do this we use the triangle inequality above showing that
|( f(x) + g(x) )-(F+G) | &= |(f(x)-F) + (g(x)-G) | \leq |f(x)-F| + |g(x)-G|
This is the key technical piece of the proof. So if we want the LHS of the above to be size \epsilon, we need to make sure that each term on the RHS is of size \frac{\epsilon}{2}. The rest of the proof is setting up facts based on the definition of limits and then rearranging facts to reach the conclusion.

p.alert: Proof of Theorem limit of a sum.

proof.p:
Let a \in \mathbb{R} and assume that
\lim_{x \to a} f(x) &= F & \text{ and } && \lim_{x \to a} g(x) &= G.
We wish to show that
\lim_{x \to a} f(x)+g(x) &= F+G.
Let \epsilon \gt 0 we have to find a \delta \gt 0 so that when |x-a| \lt \delta we have |(f(x)+g(x))-(F+G)| \lt \epsilon.

Let \epsilon \gt 0 and set \epsilon_1 = \epsilon_2 = \frac{\epsilon}{2}. By the definition of limits, because f(x) \to F there exists some \delta_1 \gt 0 so that whenever |x-a| \lt \delta_1, we also have |f(x)-F| \lt \epsilon_1. Similarly there exists \delta_2 \gt 0 so that if |x-a| \lt \delta_2, then we must have |g(x)-G| \lt \epsilon_2. So now choose \delta = \min\{ \delta_1, \delta_2 \} and assume |x-a| \lt \delta. Then we must have that |x-a| \lt \delta_1, \delta_2 and so we also have
|f(x)-F|& \lt \epsilon_1 & |g(x)-G|& \lt \epsilon_2

Now consider |(f(x)+g(x))-(F+G)| and rearrange the terms:
|(f(x)+g(x))-(F+G)| &= |(f(x)-F)+(g(x)-G)|
now apply triangle inequality
&\leq |f(x)-F| + |g(x)-G| & \text{ use facts from above}
& \lt \epsilon_1 + \epsilon_2
&= \epsilon.

Hence we have shown that for any \epsilon \gt 0 there exists some \delta \gt 0 so that when |x-a| \lt \delta we also have |(f(x)+g(x))-(F+G)| \lt \epsilon. Which is exactly the formal definition of the limit we needed to prove.

introduction.p:
As was the case in the previous proof, we want the LHS to be of size at most \epsilon, so we want, for example, the two terms on the RHS to be of size at most \frac{\epsilon}{2}. This means
we need |G|\cdot|f(x)-F| to be of size at most \frac{\epsilon}{2}, and
we need |g(x)-G| to be of size at most \frac{\epsilon}{2(|F|+1)} since we know that |f(x)| \leq |F|+1 when x is close to a.
Armed with these tricks we turn to the proofs.

p.alert: Proof of Theorem limit of a product.

proof.p:
Let a \in \mathbb{R} and assume that
\lim_{x \to a} f(x) &= F & \text{ and } && \lim_{x \to a} g(x) &= G.
We wish to show that
\lim_{x \to a} f(x)\cdot g(x) &= F\cdot G.

Let \epsilon \gt 0. Set \epsilon_1 = \frac{\epsilon}{2(|G|+1)} (the extra +1 in the denominator is just there to make sure that \epsilon_1 is welldefined even if G=0), and \epsilon_2 = \frac{\epsilon}{2(|F|+1)}. From this we establish the existence of \delta_1, \delta_2, \delta_3 which we need below.
By assumption f(x) \to F so there exists \delta_1 \gt 0 so that whenever |x-a| \lt \delta_1, we also have |f(x)-F| \lt \epsilon_1.
Similarly because g(x) \to G, there exists \delta_2 \gt 0 so that whenever |x-a| \lt \delta_2, we also have |g(x)-G| \lt \epsilon_2.
By Lemma there exists \delta_3 \gt 0 so that whenever |x-a| \lt \delta_3, we also have |f(x)| \leq |F|+1.

Let \delta = \min\{\delta_1, \delta_2, \delta_3 \}, assume |x-a| \lt \delta and consider |f(x) \cdot g(x) - F\cdot G|. Rearrange the terms as we did above:
| f(x) \cdot g(x) - F\cdot G | &= |f(x)\cdot( g(x)-G) + (f(x)-F)\cdot G |
& \leq |f(x)| \cdot |g(x)-G| + |G| \cdot |f(x)-F|
By our three dot-points above we know that |f(x)-F| \lt \epsilon_1 and |g(x)-G| \lt \epsilon_2 and |f(x)| \leq |F|+1, so we have
| f(x) \cdot g(x) - F\cdot G | & \lt |f(x)| \cdot \epsilon_2 + |G| \cdot \epsilon_1
sub in \epsilon_1,\epsilon_2 and bound on f(x)
& \lt (|F|+1) \cdot \frac{\epsilon}{2(|F|+1)} + |G|\cdot\frac{\epsilon}{2(|G|+1)}
&\leq \frac{\epsilon}{2} + \frac{\epsilon}{2} = \epsilon.
Thus we have shown that for any \epsilon \gt 0 there exists \delta \gt 0 so that when |x-a| \lt \delta we also have |f(x)\cdot g(x)-F\cdot G| \lt \epsilon. Hence f(x)\cdot g(x) \to F\cdot G.

p.alert: Proof of Theorem limit of a reciprocal.

proof.p:
Let \epsilon \gt 0 and set \epsilon_1 = \epsilon|G|^2 \cdot \frac{1}{2}. We now use this and Lemma to establish the existence of \delta_1, \delta_2.
Since g(x) \to G we know that there exists \delta_1 \gt 0 so that when |x-a| \lt \delta_1 we also have |g(x)-G| \lt \epsilon_1.
By Lemma there exists \delta_2 so that when |x-a| \lt \delta_2 we also have |g(x)| \gt \frac{|G|}{2}. Equivalently, when |x-a| \lt \delta_2 we also have \left|\frac{G}{2g(x)}\right| \lt 1.

introduction.p: We can also now prove the Squeeze / sandwich / pinch theorem.

p.alert: Proof of Theorem Squeeze / sandwich / pinch.

proof.p:
In the squeeze theorem, we are given three functions f(x), g(x) and h(x) and are told that
f(x) \leq g(x) \leq h(x) \quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{x \to a} f(x) &= \lim_{x \to a} h(x) = L
and we must conclude from this that \lim\limits_{x \to a} g(x) = L too. That is, we are given some fixed, but unspecified, \epsilon \gt 0 and it is up to us to find a \delta \gt 0 with the property that \left| g(x) - L \right| \lt \epsilon whenever |x-a| \lt \delta. Now because we have been told that f and h both converge to L, there exist \delta_1 \gt 0 and \delta_2 \gt 0 such that
\left| f(x) - L \right| \lt \epsilon, i.e. L-\epsilon \lt f(x) \lt L+\epsilon, whenever |x-a| \lt \delta_1, and
\left| h(x) - L \right| \lt \epsilon, i.e. L-\epsilon \lt h(x) \lt L+\epsilon, whenever |x-a| \lt \delta_2
So set \delta = \min\{\delta_1,\delta_2\} and assume |x-a| \lt \delta. Then both L-\epsilon \lt f(x) \lt L+\epsilon and L-\epsilon \lt h(x) \lt L+\epsilon so that
L-\epsilon \lt f(x) &\le g(x) \le h(x) \lt L+\epsilon & \text{which implies that}
L-\epsilon \lt & g(x) \lt L+\epsilon & \text{which in turn gives us}
&\left| g(x) - L \right| \lt \epsilon
as desired.
